dXiSjg0rLbhZtvDiW_gEXA.text: Disclaimer: this was my first exposure to Korean food. If I could recommend some more expert reviews to read on this, i would say check out Dan C, Ellen O, Peggy C and Christi K's posts.   I have been wanting to try this place for awhile now. Dan C. took myself and some friends here on Monday night. We put him in charge of recommendations and ordering. We got a round of appetizers for our group of five and all different entrees. I don't know what anything is called... so bear with me. App wise kimchi pancake, steamed bun and the wonton-potsticker like goodness. I went with the bbq pork with steamed rice.   Bottom line: it was all good. The seafood noodle type soup was LOADED with seafood. And best part... it's all a ton of food. We all had leftovers for the next day. Split 5 ways we each spent only $16. What a deal.  Some things to know (for those not familiar with PePeRo or Korean cuisine)  -There's a bell at your table for service.  -Try all the sides that come out with your food.  -If you're coming from Charlotte on Monroe Rd, turn before the restaurant. I drove past it and turned into the driveway on the other side which is actually for another business.  -Go explore the grocery store.   -Both the store and the restaurant take credit cards. However, please note the grocery store does have a $20 minimum.  -They do have plastic forks for the chopstick-challenged. And by chopstick challenged, I am talking about myself. This is the girl who eats sushi with her hands.  -Don't be afraid to ask questions. Someone can point you in the right direction.  I will definitely be back. I loved the vibe here. It was comforting and kind of felt like getting a homecooked meal at a relative's house.

l3OQ-rGCLd9nra0OqBmG4w.text: Inspired by Dan C's recent review and some Yelp fervor, I decided to spend Saturday in Matthews. PePeRo was my first stop. Yes, I know it's Korean but I had a couple of childhood flashbacks to NYC Chinatown when I entered. Really enjoyed stepping out of my comfort zone and trying something different. The menu was very intimidating but someone saw fit to fill in the dish descriptions below the pictures/Korean dish names (mechanical pencil?). I quickly scrolled thru the Yelp Photos and played match that picture. Warning: I will not even try to phonetically spell the dish names.  The pan fried dumplings were some of the best I've eaten. The spicy pork with rice = addictive - slight sweetness with a little afterburn. The noodle soup with beef/egg = lots of flavor and enough food for 3 people. My favorite parts were the side dishes with pickles, bean sprouts, kelp, fish cake and those cool metal rice containers (your rice stays hot the whole meal- what a concept). Definitely four stars for flavors, quantity and price. One app, two meals and drinks = only $30. Want to try the kimchee or seafood soup next visit.

HEZ8Da7B2jsXDgHLtfRq_w.text: I'm fan because PePeRo it's a spot where I can get eat an authentic Korean meal and shop for Asian food!   I'm not going to lie - it can be a bit intimidating, especially if you've never been. Let me lay it out for you - PePeRo is located in Matthews, near the intersection of John St/Monroe Rd and Hwy 51.  The entrance is located on the side of the building - there aren't a ton of parking spots but it's adequate.  When you enter, you'll be entering the market portion of PePeRo and off to the right of the entrance is the restaurant. The dining room is split into a couple different sections, I suspect from the effort to add on more dining tables. Usually, someone is there to greet you and show you to a table. It can get rather busy during peak dinner hours.  The menu is fairly straight forward - yaki mandoo, kimchi pancakes, bulgogi, etc - and it comes with the traditional banchan (side dishes).  My faves are the yaki mandoo and the kimchi pancakes.  The bulgogi portion is generous and comes with white rice. My husband usually gets the kimchi tofu soup. I've also had the cold buckwheat noodles which is yummy on a hot day!  I have to admit my favorite part about visiting PePeRo is the market - I can pick up a lot of my Asian favorites, not just Korean! I can pick up Japanese curry cubes, roasted seaweed packs, miso paste, Filipino sardines, sauces galore, as well as green tea, barley tea, and rice!     So my two cents? Don't be intimidated to visit, there's usually someone who can help you out and direct you to what you're looking for.

Kids review: The dumplings ("yaki mandoo", fried pork dumplings) were good with the sauce. The rice is really sticky but good. We liked the meat (Korean bbq with rice) the most, it was the best.   Parents review: We got one order of dol sot bibimbap in the hot pot, it was a little light on meat but so delicious. Loved how the rice got a little bit crispy in the hot pot. The chili sauce was a perfect addition. We also got an order of the spicy pork - huge portion of delicious spicy meat. Not too spicy, just right. The pickle side dishes were delicious and beautifully presented.   The only downsides were that the decor is a little drab and there's no alcohol served here. Service was great, though. vWUe6O-r4e0guSssFCHaMA.text: There's not much authentic Korean food in Charlotte and especially not in North Carolina in general.  This stuff is pretty much as good as it gets. When I lived in Charlotte, PePeRo was still about a 40 minute drive from my house. Occasionally, I'd make a special trip just to eat here because it's so damn good.  I've only tried the BiBimBap, kim chi, fish cakes, and pickled vegetables. I always order the same thing because I love it so much.  The BiBimBap is cooked properly and I always splurge and spend an extra $1 for the hot stone bowl. It's worth the extra dollar because the rice gets super crispy and crunchy at the bottom and the dish stays hot during the entire meal.  Of course, the restaurant is easy to pass by. If I didn't have it on google maps I probably would have driven right past it without even noticing it.  You have to walk through the store to get to the restaurant itself. While I admit, this can be a bit intimidating, the food makes up for the lack of decor and odd placement of the dining area. It's one of those no frills places with really awesome food. Just don't go in expecting ornate decor because it's just not that kind of restaurant.  Staff is always attentive and they have a button at every booth you can press to alert your waitress. I've never felt the need to actually use it though.   As for the store, they have lots of yummy Asian treats. Usually after dinner, I'll buy a little aloe drink or an ice cream for dessert. Some people may feel that the presence of the store detracts from the dining experience, but I disagree. I think it adds to it. Who doesn't like to eat and then shop in the same place?

8WapZT3z7cGRQkT7Se9bug.text: Coming from Atlanta (aka Korean food capital of the Southeast), I was shocked to learn how devoid of Korean restaurants the city of Charlotte is when I moved here.   My husband and I love Korean, but because Matthews is quite a drive from where we live, it took us some time to finally pay a visit to Pepero. We finally went for dinner yesterday.   The food was good - it's nothing fancy and certainly not the best Korean I've ever had, but it was reminiscent enough of Mom's home-cooked comfort Korean cuisine. I had the kimchi jjigae, which was pretty solid.   Pepero is most definitely NOT a restaurant you go to for the atmosphere. The entrance is on the side towards the building's rear, and it's surrounded by towers of boxes from food shipments. It pretty much just feels like you're eating in the middle of a small grocery store...which you technically are if you take away the wall dividing the restaurant from the store. In other words, no matter how much your crush loves Korean food, this is not the place for a first date, folks.   All in all, I would definitely go back if I was in the area, but I wouldn't drive all the way across town for it. Better start diving into some Korean cookbooks!

rCM28KL6Or_MCk_jtmDkMg.text: I ventured over with my future Korean mother-in-law for some authentic Korean groceries. I felt a bit awkward in there, being the only white person in an Asian store, but the store associates didn't stare too much. They were quiet and were super helpful when it came to carrying over a large sack of rice to our car -- an Asian staple!  I'm a big fan of Grand Asia Market, so this is like a mini-mart version with mostly Korean brands. The store layout is a little wonky -- the food isn't organized like a normal grocery store. Some of the foods are hard to figure out -- a small portion have English translations, but most I left up to my FMOL to transcribe for me. I lingered around the sweets since I am a sucker for sugar and I don't need English words to tell me what cookies or frozen mochi tastes like! Hehe! I was shocked to discover Korean "pocky" that's called "Pepero" -- not sure if it's a coincidence that the store has the same name... :) We also picked up the staple of all Korean diets: Kimchi! It's pickled cabbage that's fermented for a LOOONG time, but not something I would be able to incorporate into my daily meals (my boyfriend doesn't really like it -- shocking, I know).  Apparently, when you spend over a certain amount here, you get a package of mochi-like treats for free! They're cold, multi-colored, round, and rubbery with a sweet bean paste inside. FMOL popped them like candy, but I stuck to eating one since it's a creepy texture to chew.  I didn't notice that there's an actual restaurant in here until we were checking out! It's hidden behind a set of swinging doors (the kind you see in Westerns). Will definitely have to drop in for a bite next time! Gotta try me some Korean BBQ! ;)  *One safety concern of this store is that the Emergency Exit is completely blocked by boxes. Hopefully they can fix that soon.

gMALvtBFs3VdaNeZYVoaFw.text: As if 2011 hasn't sucked enough, I find that my favorite Korean restaurant has closed. No more Kojan Bistro! So freaking devastating. Where will I go for my Korean fix? Why are there so few Korean restaurants in Charlotte? And why are they all in Matthews? Sure I've tried Chowan Gardens, and they're ok, but what I call Asian for white people.  So I've ventured into PePeRo, and am much happier person now. They must have had a recent renovation, because the infamous counter with the sideways menu is gone. Or maybe I just couldn't find it.  There is now a nice looking dining area, with about 12-14 tables. Also a television or two, and table side service, which was more than adequate. I would have preferred an actual glass of water, as opposed to the coffee mug with minuscule amount of ice.    The food was just fabulous. The banchan is my favorite part of the Korean meal, and these did not disappoint. The garlicky cabbage and daikon kimchi, bean sprout salad, fish cakes, and radish salad were all delicious. Would have loved to had another variety in the lineup, but ask and they will replenish whatever banchan you would like. The short rib soup and bibimbap were yummy, and prices were very reasonable.  5 stars for Charlotte, maybe 4 stars for LA; but I can't afford to fly out to LA for my Korean fix all the time. This is all Charlotte has and I'm grateful for it.

R5o4aK6xLNFVkq0pcDsOfQ.text: This place is a gem! I was kind of taken back my the small unassuming exterior but went inside anyway (the entrance is to the side next to the parking!). There were two parts to this place: a restaurant on the right and a Korean/Asian store on the left. At the restaurant, I ordered the jjajangmyeon (black bean noodles) and it was great, a very filling portion size. The server was very friendly (and could speak Japanese, a major plus for me and my Japanese family lol) and made sure that everything was going good. When you order the food, they also give you a variety of small side dishes (which I believe is common in Korea and in Korean restaurants). Our side dishes were cabbage kimchi, cucumber kimchi, daikon kimchi (I think), a seaweed salad-type dish, spicy fish cakes, and pickled radish. Very tasty!  In the store section, there was a variety of asian food such as fish, kimchi, and a variety of instant noodles. The banchans can vary but tonight its bean sprouts,  seaweed,  cucumber kimchee,  regular cabbage kimchee,  and fish cakes.  It was shark eyes all around!!  Prices are reasonable for Korean food standards;  japchae was 1099 and soup was 999, and mondu 599.  So not bad!! If you are craving Korean food and are in the area Pe Pe Ro is really the only option, but I'd still say a must try!!

kffP7ig1JjRZF27UAeEGHA.text: Given the number of times I've been to Pepero in the past, can't believe I haven't written a single review on this place?!? Better late than never, so here goes...  This is probably a quintessential "hidden gem"...in that it's probably the best authentic Korean restaurant in Charlotte, yet literally "hidden" inside a rather shoddy, rough-looking Korean grocery store.   Honestly, it's a bit funny. You enter this grocery store-restaurant from a side door (as the front door is blocked for some odd reason)...and well, this side entrance area is beyond bad lol. Once you step inside, you'll see the grocery section to the left, and Pepero to the right.  Given how I always came here with my parents or friends in the past, my husband has never been here! Well, tonight, I managed to drag him out to finally check out this place.   We ordered the Seafood Pancake, Galbi and Tangsuyuk...and expected, they were all good. Tangsuyuk was solid, as always. Think Tangsuyuk, along with Jjajangmyun, has always been my favorite dishes here...though my parents always raved about their authentic stews. However, I must admit that there were a few disappointments. Though perfectly delicious, the Galbi was rather skimpy in portion...and the Seafood Pancake was really weak compared to what I had in the past here, as well as elsewhere. I was also sad to hear that they didn't carry Galbi Jjim, my ultimate favorite Korean dish. No matter, we had no problem eating every bit of what we ordered, including all of their complimentary sides.  Anyway, after our experience here, my husband agreed with my assessment of this place....that is, surprisingly good food in a "hidden" dive! Still, as much as I love the food here, I don't return here as often as I should. Why? The Flies! Possibly due to the flies' attraction to Kimchi and/or the fact that the restaurant is just inches away from the swinging door, I've had to deal with flies throughout my meals here on more than one occasion. Anyone that knows me know that I absolutely hate insects...really more of a phobia! So no, it's not about the lack of ambiance (and yes, it's quite the dive) or the sanitation grade (which is surprisingly good)...but the frickin' Flies!! I only wish they can get this problem under control.   Despite a few issues, I'm sure to return...and husband is also willing to return to try a few other popular dishes, like their amazing Jjajangmyun! Like I said, this is probably the best authentic Korean food you'll find in Charlotte...so you have to be willing to make a few compromises lol. If not, Koreatown in Duluth, GA, with its many 4-5 star Korean restaurants, is less than 4 hours away!

sFKONoY0SOfo_LewH_6xiA.text: Quaint little Korean restaurant inside a grocery store. This place is so much better than the one inside G Mart!   The hubs and I come here often whenever we get a craving for authentic Korean food and don't feel like driving 3 hours to Duluth, GA (that city is Korea-Town!)   We pretty much order the exact same thing every time we're here. I keep saying I'll try something different but our usual is so friggin delicious- why risk it?   We start with the seafood pancake which is loaded with squid, octopus, shrimp, mussels, faux crab and sometimes even scallops. This is served with a soy dipping sauce that perfectly compliments the dish without overpowering it.   My usual is jjampong, a seafood soup with veggies and Udon noodles. I can NEVER finish a bowl. Even when I share with the hubs and the rugrats, there's still leftovers- there's just so much food in one serving. The dish used to be $10 and they've sinced upped the price to $13, but let me tell you - it's worth so much more than what you pay for.   The hubs gets bulgolgi cause let's face it - that's a staple and should always be eaten when going to a Korean joint. Not getting bulgolgi is like not getting the fries at McDonald's- you just HAVE to get it!  The meat is always super flavorful and tender. It's served with Korean rice which is a short grain, slightly sticky grain, similar to what's used in sushi. I enjoy the different texture since I usually eat jasmine rice at home.   To top it all off, they serve the best ban Chan in the Charlotte area. You get kimchi, cucumber kimchi, seaweed salad, seasoned bean sprouts and my all time fave - stir fried fish cakes. I know I know - sounds pretty weird. But it's delicious! So good that I always purchase some on the side to-go so I can enjoy it when I'm eating Shin Ramen at home.   There's been a surge of new Korean joints popping up around Charlotte and some are pretty good but none is as authentic as this place. Those new spots cater to the American palette. I prefer the real deal here.

cdxQ3wn7kgfDk8PZj81aUg.text: First off, I'm Korean. I've eaten at this place on and off for 11 years with my family and friends and I recently moved back to Charlotte after being gone for 2 years. I ordered Kimchi pajun "pancake" to-go for my wife as well. When it came out, it was literally too salty (too much reduced soy sauce) to eat. I stopped and told ajumma (honorific respect word for a mature lady who isn't necessarily your family, learn a little Korean while we're at it lol). I didn't eat it. She told me she'd check and I can tell the chef/manager/owner told her that she would not remake it and she said she can add some vegetables so that it wasn't as salty...What?! This is the dishonorable part. Instead of making it over so I don't die of hypertension right there, she said could mask it with vegetables so I don't taste it as much.   She did, I tasted it...still could. So I politely got up and told the son who was at the front about my experience and he went back and talked with his mother/chef/owner/manager and said that it was all the same since I started eating there in 2007. False. Did not take off the meal at the very least I mean come on, I didn't eat it?! you've got to be kidding, is the establishment that hard up for money these days or did I turn them off? I didn't argue or make a scene to make anyone angry. Usually honor is at stake here, and this is not usually how this plays out. I am still shocked. I gave a 5 buck cash tip anyway because it wasn't ajumma's fault and for some reason I felt embarrassed bringing it up but alas I'm born and raised here and it's not ok to stick it to me...but the consequence is this review and my passion for taking friends and colleagues to enjoy my food just won't happen here. So while I'm at it Super G Mart has a Korean counter in the back and is Korean owned. They always have a better and fresher variety of groceries anyway so I guess I'll go there for now on.
